author: Redacción AN / AG
title: Videos | Trágico accidente de autobús deja al menos 19 muertos en Nicaragua | Aristegui Noticias
text: Videos | Trágico accidente de autobús deja al menos 19 muertos en Nicaragua El autobús, que iba de la ciudad de Waslala hacia Matagalpa para un retiro espiritual, se estampó contra un puente y quedó suspendido en el aire. - Redacción AN / AG Al menos 19 personas murieron y 26 resultaron heridas tras el accidente de un autobús ocurrido la mañana de este sábado en el Puente Mancera, Nicaragua. El autobús, que iba de la ciudad de Waslala hacia Matagalpa para un retiro espiritual, se estampó contra un puente y quedó suspendido en el aire. Conductor de autobús está detenido La primera hipótesis de la causa es el exceso de velocidad, por lo que el conductor se encuentra actualmente detenido para que la Policía pueda determinar su grado de responsabilidad. Te puede interesar > [Video | Aumenta a 29 los muertos tras volcadura de autobús en Oaxaca](https://aristeguinoticias.com/0507/mexico/video-aumenta-a-29-los-muertos-tras-volcadura-de-autobus-en-oaxaca/) Ocho menores muertos Entre los fallecidos por el momento se sabe que se encuentran ocho menores, seis mujeres y dos hombres, según el periódico ‘La Prensa’. Los heridos fueron trasladados al hospital por los trabajadores del Ministerio de Salud de Nicaragua (Minsa) que se han personado en el lugar del accidente. (Europa Press)

author: alfre2
title: #28 Joan Laporta se dirige a los socios: "El caso Negreira es una campaña orquestada para desprestigiar y desestabilizar el Barça".
text:
Portada
mis comunidades
otras secciones
Se está luciendo Laporta con esta estrategia de comunicación...
Pero bueno, no podemos esperar que lo admita abiertamente. Esos son sus
#valors
[#3](c3#c-3) aún recuerdo cómo Villarejo obligó a tres presidentes del FC Barcelona a pagar a Negreira cantidades ingentes de dinero por unos PDF que te los hace cualquier licenciado en comunicación audiovisual con conocimientos de fútbol.
[#11](c11#c-11) yo lo que recuerdo es una conversación entre los 2 que te he nombrado en la que descartaban destapar todo lo que sabían, ya que iba a afectar a otro club más. Y por cobardes abandonaron la idea
[#12](c12#c-12) Tengo curiosidad por ese tema. ¿Tienes algún enlace a la conversación? No la encuentro porque hay más audios de Villarejo que de la doctora Francis.
[#16](c16#c-16) Busca info sobre el "caso árbitros". Villarejo y Rajoy sostuvieron una conversación sobre la conveniencia de destapar el asunto (que cómo no, tiene grabada en algún sitio), pero al final acabó desestimado porque el asunto no implicaría únicamente al Barça, que era lo que pretendían.
[#12](c12#c-12) pues oye, vete al juzgado, yo no voy a poner la mano en el fuego por nadie y menos por un presidente de club de fútbol, habiendo conocido a Gil, Mendoza, Mareos, Núñez, etc... Pero lo de los pagos a Negreira es un hecho, te guste o no, y si no lo ves, prueba a bajarte la bufanda de los ojos.
[#18](c18#c-18) No es necesario. Los juzgados ya están dotados de personal y hasta de jueces. De hecho hay uno intentando clasificar los pagos relacionados en facturas como delito, pero no hay manera, no le sale. Tampoco llevo bufanda, está desaconsejada donde vivo.
[#20](c20#c-20) de momento lo único que no le sale es el cohecho un intento desesperado para que no se le escapars Laporta por prescripción del delito, todo por una bonita ley modificada exprés a las puertas de que saliera todo esto.
[#22](c22#c-22) no lo obvio, lo señalo, el intento de aplicar el cohecho fue una acción desesperada para evitar que Laporta escapara indemne por prescripción del presunto delito. Lo cual no implica que el delito se pueda tipificar de otra forma, existiera, prescribiera (gracias ministro!!) y escape... Cosa que tiene mucho más difícil el Barto.
Ten cuidado no te suba la temperatura, las bufandas en zonas de calor fríen cerebros.
[#23](c23#c-23) Ojo, en ese caso quizás sea el juez el que incurre en un delito al tratar de imputar por lo que sea a alguien a sabiendas de que lo hace falsamente. Eso hablaría mucho peor del juez que de Laporta, inocente hasta que se demuestre lo contrario (cosa que no ha ocurrido).
[#24](c24#c-24) pues que vaya Laporta y denuncie al juez. Cuando se condene a Bartomeu veremos que pasa, si se lo come tan agusto o saca mierda de su antecesores que se van de rositas siendo los que iniciaron el chiringuito Negreira.
[#26](c26#c-26) Jan ni inocente ni no culpable, no es juzgable por qué de lo que se le acusa está prescrito, simplemente no hay causa. Sandro y Barto veremos pero pinta feo, los pagos y facturas están ahí, la declaración de Enrique Negreira está ahí, otros indicios aportados por la Guardia Civil están ahi.
Y el Barcelona como club también puede salir perjudicado con independencia de quien sea su presidente actualmente, como si mañana entra Font.
Aún queda tiempo me parece a mí, no hay deseos políticos que esto avance, es malo para todos, mientras que si se queda como está habrá sido malo solo para algunos y ya está pasado, el presente manda.
[#27](c27#c-27) hasta que llegue el momento, por lo que se está viendo, no hay ni un solo experto que pueda explicar dónde está el delito concreto que se persigue y qué podría suponer. Todo es una cábala, todo tiene mala pinta, todo es un mal augurio… pero sin la menor concreción
[#1](c1#c-1) Al menos podría no decir nada, si ya tenemos todos claro que esto no va a llegar a ninguna parte.
Este lo que tendría que hacer es dimitir. Después de la canallada que le ha hecho a Xavi y como engañó a todos con lo de Messi.

author: Luca Ronco
title: Studenti sorpresi: arrivano i primi rimborsi dell'Università di Torino, che restituisce agli allievi 39 milioni di euro
text:
Attualità
Studenti sorpresi: arrivano i primi rimborsi dell'Università di Torino, che restituisce agli allievi 39 milioni di euro
Dopo la condanna del Consiglio di stato per le tasse illegittime del 2018
Sono arrivati in questi giorni i primi rimborsi dell’Università di Torino ai suoi studenti, per le tasse illegittime chieste nel 2018. Gli allievi stanno ricevendo i soldi a cui hanno diritto tramite bonifico, sul conto corrente da loro indicato. Molti non nascondono la sorpresa, visto che temevano tempi più lunghi per lo svolgimento di queste procedure.
Perché i rimborsi
L’anno scorso, il Consiglio di stato ha condannato l’Università, ribaltando una precedente sentenza del Tar, perché avrebbe imposto agli studenti una tassazione oltre ai massimi consentiti dalla legge. Era stata l’Unione degli universitari (Udu), nel 2018, ad avviare la causa su questo tema.
Una legge in vigore, infatti, prevede che le Università chiedano tasse per un importo massimo del 20% di quello ricevuto dal Fondo per il finanziamento ordinario. Nel 2018, quella di Torino, aveva ricevuto 277 milioni. Per questo, non avrebbe dovuto chiederne più di 55. Invece, tassava i suoi studenti per un totale di 94 milioni di euro.
Adesso deve restituire circa 39 milioni di euro.
Chi ha diritto al rimborso
Il 4 febbraio 2025, l’Università aveva avviato il procedimento per restituire il denaro a chi ne ha diritto, avvisando gli iscritti con questo comunicato ufficiale. Può ancora presentare domanda di rimborso chi, nel 2018, ha versato dei contributi per l’iscrizione o l’immatricolazione a corsi di studio di primo o secondo livello (laurea, laurea specialistica, laurea magistrale, laurea magistrale a ciclo unico, laurea vecchio ordinamento).
Come ottenere il rimborso
Sarà rimborsato il 33,37% della contribuzione versata nel 2018, riferita agli anni accademici 2017-2018 e 2018-2019. Ogni studente (o ex studente) deve presentare autonomamente la richiesta, solo in modalità digitale, accedendo alla piattaforma MyUnito con le proprie credenziali. Se le credenziali sono state disattivate, si può effettuare il login tramite Spid.
Una volta entrati nella piattaforma, bisogna seguire il percorso Iscrizioni / Iniziative / Rimborso quote eccedenti di contribuzione versate nell’anno solare 2018.
Iscriviti al canale TorinoToday su WhatsApp, segui la nostra pagina Facebook e continua a leggere TorinoToday.

author: Geoff Bansen
title: Great start to the weekend, but big changes on the way
text:
2 hours ago Geoff Bansen ,
We have incredible weather lined up for Saturday. Full sunshine is expected, with temperatures in the low 70s. It will be quite breezy however! Gusts up to 30 mph are expected.
Unfortunately, things go downhill fast into Sunday. A warm front will move into the Northeast, and depending on exact placement, temperatures may not get out of the 50s!
It will naturally also bring cloudy skies along with it, with some passing showers too.
The warm front will lift north into Sunday night and briefly dry things out, but a cold front approaches Columbus Day Monday and shower chances eventually return.
There could even be a thunderstorm along the way. The cold front passes Monday night and while dry weather returns for the rest of the week, a fall chill returns as well.
Daytime temperatures won’t get out of the 50s Tuesday and Wednesday, with overnights dropping into the 30s!
As a result, we will see widespread frost; for those that didn’t get any early this morning, it will likely be the first of the year.
Categories : News , Weather Forecast Facebook Pinterest Twitter Linkedin

author: AB Newswire
title: Master Garage Door Repairs with Expert Guidance from Firstline Garage Door Repair | User | bigspringherald.com
text:
Chicago, United States - January 23, 2025 - Firstline Garage Door Repair is proud to unveil its comprehensive guide, offering 20 actionable steps to tackle common garage door problems independently. With over a decade of industry expertise, the company empowers homeowners to troubleshoot issues, ensure safety, and save costs—all while highlighting the importance of professional assistance for complex repairs.
From non-functioning safety sensors to seasonal challenges like frozen garage doors, Firstline's guide provides detailed instructions, practical tips, and safety precautions to help homeowners navigate various garage door concerns. Below are highlights from the guide that address some of the most frequent garage door issues:
Safety Sensor Malfunction
Safety sensors are vital for preventing accidents and ensuring smooth operation. Misaligned sensors, dirty lenses, or broken wires can disrupt functionality. Homeowners are encouraged to:
Adjust sensors to ensure they are parallel.
Clean sensors every six months to remove debris.
Inspect and tighten bolts, or call a technician for wiring issues.
Power Outages and Battery Backup Failures
Power disruptions often leave homeowners stranded. If the garage door opener fails during an outage, checking the electrical outlet and testing the battery backup system are crucial first steps. Firstline advises replacing worn-out batteries or consulting professionals for advanced troubleshooting.
Common Mechanical Failures
Trolley Breakdowns: When the opener sounds active, but the door doesn’t move, the trolley might need reconnecting. Broken trolleys should be repaired or replaced by professionals.
Spring Breakage: Broken springs are hazardous to repair independently. Firstline emphasizes calling certified technicians to ensure safety and proper installation.
Seasonal Challenges: Winter Freezing
In colder climates, ice and snow can freeze garage doors shut. Homeowners are encouraged to use hot water to melt ice carefully and lubricate moving parts regularly to prevent such occurrences.
Track Obstructions and Roller Maintenance
Dirty tracks, hardened grease, or misaligned bolts can obstruct door movement. Regular cleaning, lubrication, and visual inspections are recommended to prevent breakdowns. For bottom rollers, which are under high tension, professional assistance is advised.
Wi-Fi Connectivity and Remote Access Issues
Modern garage doors often rely on Wi-Fi and smartphone apps. When this functionality fails, Firstline suggests:
Checking the router signal.
Rebooting both the opener and the phone.
Consulting the app provider or a technician for persistent problems.
Importance of Force Adjustment and Annual Maintenance
Force settings protect both your property and family. Improper adjustments or worn springs can cause operational errors. Firstline’s guide underscores the value of annual maintenance to balance springs, lubricate components, and avoid costly repairs.
Broken Cables, Mounts, and Structural Damage
Rust, wear, or loose bolts can cause cables to break, tracks to misalign, or mounts to fail. These issues often require professional tools and expertise. Firstline offers free consultations and efficient repair services to address such complex problems safely.
Firstline’s Commitment to Excellence
Garage door repairs are often seen as daunting, but with the right guidance, many issues can be resolved independently. At the same time, we emphasize safety and encourage homeowners to seek professional help for high-risk repairs like spring replacements and structural reinforcements.
With their user-friendly guide, Firstline Garage Door Repair empowers homeowners to take control of minor fixes while providing top-notch services for more complicated issues.
About Firstline Garage Door Repair
Firstline Garage Door Repair has been a trusted name in the industry for over ten years. Specializing in installation, repair, and maintenance, their team combines expertise with personalized customer care. Serving Illinois and surrounding areas, Firstline is committed to delivering reliable, efficient, and safe garage door solutions.
For more information on Firstline’s guide or to schedule a free consultation, visit the website or contact at Email: info@firstlinegarage.com
Media Contact

Contact Person: Alex Caraus
Email: Send Email

Country: United States
Website: https://firstlinegarage.com/

author: Xinhua
title: Israeli air force chief says Israel "ready" for war against Hezbollah-Xinhua
text:
JERUSALEM, June 27 (Xinhua) -- Israeli Air Force Commander Tomer Bar said on Thursday that the country's forces are "ready" for a war against Hezbollah in Lebanon.
"Attacking the enemy in its own territory -- that is the ultimate solution," Bar spoke at a pilot course graduation ceremony, claiming that Israel is "ready against Hezbollah."
"We have the means for it, we have the capabilities, and certainly, we have the patience and fighting spirit," he said.
Bar's remarks echoed Defense Minister Yoav Gallant's warning on Wednesday, who said during his visit to Washington that while the Israeli government prefers a diplomatic solution, the Israeli forces are capable of taking Lebanon "back to the Stone Age."
Earlier on Thursday, the Israeli army announced that it had killed a Hezbollah militant belonging to the Lebanese armed group's air forces, who had been deploying drones towards Israel. Subsequently, two aircraft that transgressed from Lebanon into Israeli territory crashed in the vicinity of the Rosh Hanikra community near the border, according to the military, who noted that no injuries were reported.
On the same day, Israel's Haaretz newspaper reported that U.S. officials had cautioned Israel that even a limited ground operation in southern Lebanon could spark a full-scale conflict involving Iran and its allies. ■

author: Isabeau Doucet
title: ‘It’s impossible to celebrate’: Gaza war opens fissures among US Christians | Christianity | The Guardian
text:
In Bethlehem in the West Bank, the birthplace of Jesus, Christmas has been canceled. There will be no trees, no lights, no choirs or celebrations.
Instead of a manger, at the Lutheran church in Bethlehem, the baby Jesus lies swaddled in a keffiyeh , half buried in a pile of rubble.
“It’s impossible to celebrate when there’s a massacre, a genocide, taking place in Gaza with our people,” Pastor Munther Ishaq, told Al Jazeera .
In the US, some Christians are following suit. “The only gift that Palestinians want to have is a Christmas ceasefire gift,” said the Rev Khader Khalila, who grew up in Bethlehem, and is now at The Redeemer-St John’s Lutheran church in Brooklyn. Khalila will not be exchanging gifts this year, even with his own two children, and will instead donate money to organizations helping children in Gaza and rebuilding efforts.
The United States is home to the world’s largest population of Christians – a diverse faith group profoundly divided along denominational and political lines. These divisions are on stark display when it comes to the war in holy land.
A scene of the nativity of Christ with a figure of baby Jesus swaddled in a keffiyeh, half buried in a pile of rubble, inside the Evangelical Lutheran church in Bethlehem in the West Bank, on 6 December. Photograph: Hazem Bader/AFP/Getty Images Shortly after Hamas’s 7 October attacks on southern Israel, some 90 pastors and other leaders signed an “ Evangelical Statement in Support of Israel ” condemning Hamas. “In keeping with Christian Just War tradition, we also affirm the legitimacy of Israel’s right to respond against those who have initiated these attacks,” the letter read. Among its signatories was the president of the Southern Baptist Convention, who represents the largest evangelical Protestant group in the US with about 13 million members.
A very different letter was sent to President Joe Biden on 9 November from Churches for Middle East Peace (CMEP) and 30 American Christian leaders, calling for the administration to “support an immediate ceasefire, de-escalation, and restraint by all involved”. It was signed by representatives of the Presbyterian, Methodist, Episcopal, United, Lutheran and Orthodox churches, among others.
Evangelical Protestants, who lean more Republican , account for about 24% of the adult US population, according to 2021 Pew Research Center research. Catholics account for 21%, and non-evangelical or “mainline” Protestants, who lean more moderate or liberal , account for about 16%. In terms of support for the Israeli government, 68% of white evangelicals express a very or somewhat favorable view, while only 50% of Catholics and 51% of white non-evangelical Protestants feel that way, according to 2022 Pew polls.
The Evangelical Lutheran Church in America ( ELCA ), which has nearly 4 million congregants, denounced both Hamas and Israel’s retaliation, but said that the “power exerted against all Palestinian people – through the occupation, the expansion of settlements and the escalating violence – must be called out as a root cause of what we are witnessing”.
But even supporters of Israel are concerned about the mounting death toll in Gaza.
Earlier this month, two women were shot dead by Israeli snipers while taking refuge inside a church in Gaza, and seven others were wounded.
Most of the Christians left in Gaza – some 800-1,000 of them – have been sheltering in two churches. Pope Francis condemned the killings and suggested Israel was using “terrorism” tactics across the strip.
“I think Christmas should go on because in some ways, it’s a protest against the war and violence in the world,” said Daniel Darling, a signatory to the letter in support of Israel and director of the Land Center for Cultural Engagement at Southwestern Baptist Theological Seminary in Fort Worth, Texas.
Darling has visited Israel four times on Christian tours and feels attached to the state in part because his grandparents were Jews who had fled pogroms in Poland and Russia.
“It doesn’t mean there’s a blank check for the Israeli government,” said Darling, adding, “I do hold Hamas responsible, in large part, for the plight of their people.”
American evangelical support for Israel is tied into beliefs about the state’s role in accelerating the second coming of Christ . “I think we all agree that he’s coming soon,” said Darling, referring to the epic battle of Armageddon where Jesus returns to earth.
More progressive denominations have taken a much firmer stance against Israel’s military campaign.
Susan Wilder, a minister at the Grace Presbyterian church in Springfield, Virginia, joined an international delegation of Christian leaders spending Christmas in Bethlehem in solidarity with the Palestinians. She worries about US complicity in the war: “We haven’t been a good friend to Israel in really calling them to halt these atrocities that’s essentially genocide on display for all the world to see.”
​The Presbyterian Church (USA), representing 1.1 million members, voted in the summer of 2022 to declare Israel an apartheid state . They previously called for US aid to Israel to be conditional on compliance with US law and voted to boycott settlement products and divest from companies that profit from Israel’s occupation of Palestinian territories.
This Christmas, Wilder’s church will conduct a “prayer of mourning and solidarity” with a Christian congregation in the occupied West Bank city of Nablus. They have had a partnership with the Palestinian congregation for the past 16 years, but “this is the worst the situation has ever been for them”, said Wilder referring to the death toll in besieged Gaza and settler violence in the West Bank.
While the Presbyterian church’s stance, along with the United Church of Christ, may be the most robust in their criticism of Israel’s decades-long occupation, they are not alone, says Philip Farah , founder of Palestinian Christian Alliance for Peace. “The majority of mainline Protestant denominations in the US have divested their pension funds from companies that profit from the Israeli occupation of Palestine and the majority have passed resolutions calling for the boycott of products made in the illegal Israeli settlements.”
While the Vatican has been very critical of Israel’s bombardment, its US representatives have been notably more muted.
There are more than 60 million Catholics in the US – Joe Biden is one of them. While the pope has repeatedly called for a ceasefire. the president of the US Conference of Catholic Bishops (USCCB) has avoided using the word, opting instead for an “immediate cessation of all hostilities”, along with prayers for peace.
The USCCB has been quiet and unwilling to help mobilize the public to take the action needed to pressure political leaders, said Eli McCarthy, a professor at Georgetown University in justice and peace studies and a member of the Franciscan Action Network.
“They have also said nothing about sending weapons to Israel, much less the Pentagon budget in general,” McCarthy said. “What I think we see here is the difference between nationalism and Catholicism.”
Explore more on these topics Christianity Religion Israel-Gaza war features
